Award.AwardTitle: Faculty Seminars on the Improvement of Teaching in the STEM Disciplines

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Science educators benefit from professional development to learn about and implement evidence-based teaching practices. To this end, the Council of Independent Colleges is convening a Seminar on STEM Pedagogy, to be held July 15-19, 2019 in Oakland, California. Teams from ten independent colleges will attend the seminar to study how students learn and to develop teaching practices that can improve STEM learning at their institutions. Three highly experienced STEM faculty members will serve as facilitators for the seminar to help participants develop activities integrating evidence-based practices that they will then implement at their home institutions.

The Seminar in STEM Pedagogy seeks to disseminate ideas developed by Nobel prize-winner Carl Wieman for improving STEM teaching and learning. Teams of faculty and administrators from ten independent colleges will participate in the seminar where they will explore the psychology of learning, student motivation, and deliberate practice as they develop learning goals and assessment activities for courses at their home institutions. Seminar activities will be recorded and materials disseminated to the 656 member institutions of the Council of Independent Colleges to further spread evidence-based teaching practices to small independent colleges.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Council of Independent Colleges' Seminar on Science Pedagogy

Project Outcomes Report

The Council of Independent Colleges' (CIC) first Seminar on Science Pedagogy took place July 15-19, 2019, on the campus of Holy Names University in Oakland, California. The seminar was designed to improve teaching effectiveness and student learning in introductory biology, chemistry, and physics courses on CIC member campuses. Ten institutional teams, selected from a total of 34 applications, participated in the seminar. Each team consisted of three to four faculty members (including at least one department chair, dean, or other administrator) from one or two departments.

The teams spent the 2018-2019 academic year collecting baseline data on student learning in existing classes, reflecting on current teaching and learning practices, and beginning to examine and discuss resources on active learning and student cognition. The five-day seminar drew on an active learning model championed by Nobel laureate Carl Wieman, professor of physics and education at Stanford University. The model, which has a strong foundation in cognitive learning research, has been implemented, with proven success, at large research universities. The Seminar was aimed at the implementation of the model and its methods in science departments at small to mid-sized institutions.

At the seminar, faculty members participated in discussions and activities that helped them learn to construct courses that align learning goals and assessment, challenge students to think deeply about increasingly complex problems, and provide the prompt and extensive feedback that is most effective in student learning. The seminar facilitators led active sessions on topics such as cognitive load and memory, knowledge organization, inclusive teaching, feedback for learning, learning goals, backward design of courses and activities, self-directed learning, building expertise in students, helping students organize their knowledge in easily retrievable ways, and using quick-response techniques for student learning. Faculty members also learned that the cognitive load produced from learning new material can be reduced by removing details that require extraneous processing, managing essential processing, and fostering deep thinking about questions and problems involving key concepts.

Before, throughout, and after the seminar, participants used background readings as the starting point for group discussions. Texts participants read included Improving How Universities Teach Science: Lessons from the Science Education Initiative, by Carl Wieman; How Learning Works: Seven Research-Based Principles for Smart Teaching, by Susan A. Ambrose, et al.; research articles on evidence-based techniques for improving student learning and effective assessment of student learning; and a handbook on building courses that actively engage students in learning to think like a scientist.

Participants were also briefed on assessment procedures for their revised courses in order to determine what sections of revised courses were working and which still needed improvement. Team members introduced the new teaching and learning methods they learned into one or two introductory science courses over the 2019-2020 academic year, measured the impact of the new methods, and are to revise additional courses for the 2020-2021 academic year.

The COVID-19 pandemic closed all of the participating campuses in the middle of the spring 2020 semester and forced all revised courses into online formats. Data collection on the effectiveness of course revisions was disrupted for that semester and will continue in the fall 2020 semester. Preliminary data indicate that course revisions were engaging for students and faculty members. Qualitative comments indicate that the Seminar methods helped faculty members quickly adapt to online learning formats while maintaining a quality learning environment for students.

Reports on the outcomes of the project will be made to CIC-member chief academic officers at the CIC Institute for Chief Academic Officers, to be held online in November, 2020, and (we hope) in person in November 2021, and will be made available to the over 350 department chairs who participate in the CIC Workshops for Department and Division Chairs each year. In addition, a report on the long-term results will be included in the CIC newsletter, The Independent. The project evaluator also intends to publish the conglomerated evaluation data. Participants were encouraged to present the results of their campus's experience with the course revisions at local, regional, and national disciplinary science education meetings.
